actual.value:
Below is the list of the learning objectives that were mentioned in the proposal and how the TMT helped in reaching them.
· **Defining and describing the concepts of good water governance: **
Participants had access to self-paced interactive training modules, followed by online discussions with the training team and experts, on:
- The need for good water governance
- An overview of water governance frameworks
- The integrated and multi-sectoral approaches for water governance
- Lessons learned on good water governance
- Institutional frameworks of multilevel water governance
- (Inter)national water cooperation and diplomacy
- Climate change and what it means in terms of effective water management
· **Analysing the current water governance system in the country and identifying the main issues that are hampering its good performance:**
Participants completed in groups the two following exercises, and received afterwards written and oral feedback from the training team:
- Analysis of the status of water governance in Bhutan based on the OECD's 12 Principles on Water Governance
- Identification and analysis of the causes and root causes of water challenges facing Bhutan using the mind map and Ishikawa diagram tools.
After the identification of the lack of reliable data by participants as a main water governance challenge in Bhutan, a 4-day face to face workshop was organised. This training activity aimed at building the knowledge and skills of the MoWHS staff and a number of their partners on data collection and sampling methods, and to establish an accurate water data baseline.
· **Analysing the linkages between the management and governance of irrigation and drinking water:**
Participants had access to self-paced interactive training modules on:
- Water for Irrigation
- Public private partnerships
- Drinking water supply
- Water pricing
During the live online meetings, the participants discussed among each other and with the experts the advantages and disadvantages of combining irrigation and drinking water responsibilities under the mandates of the new water agency in Bhutan.
· **Discussing the success factors of international good practices of water governance:**
Participants had access to two recorded Powerpoints by senior water expert Wouter Wolters on:
- Examples of irrigation modernisation processes from around the world
- Experiences of Australia, Mexico and Pakistan with water governance reform
Furthermore, based on the demand of the group, Wouter Wolters prepared a report about the lessons learnt from water reforms in Israel and gave his advice on which of these lessons can be relevant to the Bhutanese context.
Finally, all the experts that were involved in the training where asked to share international case studies and best practices related to water governance in their modules and online presentations. Some discussed examples:
- The institutional frameworks of multilevel water governance in South Africa by expert Eiman Karar
- Water related climate adaptation in In the Hindu Kush Himalaya region by expert Christian Siderius
· **Designing an action plan to restructure the institutional set up for drinking water and irrigation, and to create a separate water agency initially responsible for drinking water and irrigation.**
- Participants mapped the stakeholders that have interest in or influence on irrigation and drinking water services in Bhutan, and discussed their different roles and relationships
- Participants followed two training modules on water for irrigation and drinking water
- Participants prepared a draft proposal of an action plan with recommendations to establish the new Bhutan water agency, received feedback from THA training team and experts, and submitted the improved draft to the Royal Government of Bhutan
· **Assessing the possibility of including the management and governance of other water activities, such as sanitation, under the mandates of the new agency that will be created:**
-The advantages and disadvantages of combining different water mandates under one water authority were discussed by expert Wouter Wolters and the representative of MoWHS during their continuous communication through all the project.
-The topic was discussed with the rest of the participants and experts Eiman Karar and Wouter Wolters during the live online meeting that followed the module on the institutional frameworks of multilevel water governance.
**Lessons learnt and recommendations for the future:**
An ambitious and impressive list of improving the governance and management of water has been suggested by the participants. This is an indicator of their awareness and willingness to make a change. Yet, all the actions need to be made more SMART (specific, measurable, achievable, realistic and time-related). This requires a serious recognition and investment of the Bhutan government to enable its staff to make the required efforts.
One important achievement from this training is that the participants acquired a clearer view of what it takes to establish ‘a new water agency’. A coordinated approach of planning and management when thinking about national water policy will also call for more than one Ministry involved.
There is a lack of reliable water ‘data’ which is a crucial challenge towards achieving good governance. The final training activity in this TMT consisted of face to face workshop on data collection, sampling and creating a data baseline. This is a step in the good direction. However, this data need to be further developed and to remain up-to-date. This requires more fianncial investment by the government, especially to collect the missing data from rural areas.
Science-based decision making is an issue in Bhutan, mainly because there is a little ‘knowledge infrastructure’ in terms of colleges or universities or other institutions. More capacity building and educational programmes need to be implemented. Therefore, THA and MoWHS highly recommend to bring back Bhutan to the list of eligible countries for OKP TMT projects and individual scholarships.

actual.value:
++Output 1 in the proposal:++ Increase the knowledge of 8 staff of MoWHS in the field of water governance and management.
This output was completely achieved as 16 staff of MoWHS increased their knowledge in water governance and management through the following activities:
A. 16/16 attended the first online training
7/16 attended the second online training
6 additional staff of MoWHS attended only the 4-day face to face workshop to increase their knowledge on data collection and sampling. These participants were not considered as graduates from the training since they did not complete any of the online modules on water governance. Nevertheless, they got trained on a crucial aspect of water management that is relevant for their jobs and will have access to the online training material.
In total, 22 staff of MoWHS took part in the different training activities of this project.
Adding to that, it is worth mentioning again that 3 staff from The National Environment
Commission Secretariat, completed the second online training and gained knowledge in water governance and management, while three staff of local governments and one of the Ministry of Health completed the face to face workshop on data collection and sampling.
B. The 16 participants who attended the first online training drafted an action plan to establish the new Bhutan water agency. After receiving feedback from the training team and completing the first online training, they improved the draft and submitted it to the Royal Government of Bhutan. Six of these participants are currently involved in the follow up on the implementation of the action plan.
++Output 2 in the proposal:++ MoWHS is able to begin with working on the tasks assigned by the Royal Government of Bhutan
As mentioned in the proposal, The Royal Government of Bhutan has asked the MoWHS to accomplish the following tasks:
• Task1: Identifying and analysing the issues that are hampering good water governance
• Task 2: Restructuring the various water mandates in the kingdom
• Task 3: Creating a separate water agency responsible for drinking water and irrigation
Output 2 was completely achieved according to the following means of verification:
++For task 1++:
At the end of the first online training on ‘good water governance’, a report was submitted by MoWHS to the Royal Government of Bhutan identifying and describing the main challenges in the water sector. This report was reviewed twice by the training team who provided MoWHS with feedback.
These challenges are: lack of coordination among the different ministries and agencies managing water, mismanagement of the allocated budget for water services, inadequate infrastructure and lack of infrastructure maintenance, lack of competency among water professionals, lack of available and up-to-date water data, lack of protection of water sources and poor monitoring of service delivery.
++For task 2:++
During the second online training on ‘restructuring water governance and management in Bhutan’, participants were requested by THA to suggest in writing concrete actions that their departments should implement in the ongoing water policy reform process. The actions that were identified related to the topics of: climate change adaptation, public policy making processes, administrative reforms, managing drinking water and water for irrigation, and national/local cooperation between relevant water stakeholders.
During the online closing meeting for this TMT, participants and experts were asked by THA to share their lessons learnt and final recommendations to restructuring water governance in Bhutan. Senior officials from MoWHS attended this meeting and became aware of the participants recommendations.
Although no official document has been drafted yet to create an overview of the suggested actions and recommendations above, all the information (written answers and the recorded online meeting) is archived on the online platform of the TMT project, and will remain accessible for MoWHS in the future.
++For task 3:++
As mentioned in the first part of this question, the participants who attended the first online training submitted to the Royal Government of Bhutan an action plan with recommendations to establish the new Bhutan water agency, and 6 of these participants have been following up with the government on the implementation of the action plan.

comment.narrative:
29-03-2022: The TMT consisted of three main training activities: • A first in depth online training on ‘good water governance’ from 23 November until 9 December 2020. • A second in depth online training on ‘restructuring the governance and management of water in Bhutan’ from 27 September until 1 November 2021. • A 4-day face to face workshop in Bhutan on ‘Water data collection and sampling’ from 18 until 21 October 2021.
The 19 participants that are considered graduates and who received their certificates attended at least one of the two in depth online trainings.
Overall: • 16/19 graduates attended the first online training • 10/19 graduates attended the second online training
10 additional participants (4 males and 6 females) attended only the 4-day face to face workshop. However, they are not considered graduates since they did not participate in any of the two in depth online trainings.
All together 19+10= 29 participants where trained within this TMT.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative:
31-03-2022: The seven organisations that were strengthened by the group training are:
• The Ministry of Works and Human Settlement which is the requesting organisation for this TMT and from which 22 staff members were trained.
• The Hague Academy for Local Governance: THA and its associated experts became more knowledgeable of the Bhutanese context and gained a wider understanding of the topics of good water governance and water policy reforms.
• The National Environment Commission (NEC) Secretariat: This organisation was not initially one of the requesting organisations in the proposal. However, after concluding the first online training, it became clear that there is a need for the MoWHS to work and consult different stakeholders to initiate the new water agency and plan for the water policy reform.
Due to it is crucial role in decision making on all the matters relating to the protection, conservation and improvement of the natural environment in Bhutan, 5 participants from the NEC were invited to join the second online training, of which three successfully completed it.
The three graduates expressed how important it was for them to learn about water governance, and to exchange with the staff of the MoWHS and the experts about the topic. From their side, the NEC brought the environmental perspective to the discussion and were a great addition especially to the modules on climate change and food security.
• Three participants from three local governments (Paro Dzongkhag, Paro Municipality and Thimphu Thromde) and one participant from the Ministry of Health were invited to attend the 4-day face to face workshop on water data collection and sampling. These organisations represent some of the main partners of MoWHS in managing water at the local level. Their input and local knowledge were crucial to the success of the workshop, and to effectively plan the future steps to keep the collected data up to date.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
The Hague Academy measured in different ways (questionnaires, written exercises and plenary discussions) the change in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes that resulted from the TMT project. Below, we illustrate some aspects of this change.
After attending the first online training, participants expressed by answering a questionnaire how the different modules and online sessions on ‘good water governance’ were beneficial to their personal and professional development. Some of their reactions are:
· ‘We learnt about the importance of engaging stakeholders for good water governance’. This point was mentioned by three participants.
· ‘The knowledge gained from this training will definitely help me make positive contribution to the water sector in Bhutan since I am closely involved in both policy and technical related work.’
· ‘As our Ministry is mandated with water and wastewater responsibilities, the training was very much relevant to us. The knowledge gained from this training will be useful in developing our proposal in reforming the institutional setup for water sector in our country.’
After attending the second online training on ‘restructuring the governance and management of water in Bhutan’, participants were asked to share in writing on the online platform of the course their main takeaway lessons on each of the discussed topics, and that are relevant to their context. From their input, the change in their attitudes is visible and the actions that they want to take to improve water governance and management are concrete. Some of their answers are:
· ‘It was good to learn about the various phases of the public policy cycle. Take away for me was developing optimal solutions considering resources available, being realistic, having specific budget for water and importance of evidence based policy.’
· ‘Climate change is real. Things will get worse. Mountainous countries and mountain people like us will be affected more. We need to prepare and adapt to severe weather patterns. Should engage local governments and local people for effective adaptation measures.’
· ‘The excellent synthesis of the eight policy actions from the Comprehensive Assessment was informative in understanding the way forward for the irrigation sector. I feel even after 14 years, the recommendations in our context are still relevant, and some steps in the right direction have been taken by the government.’
· ‘There is a need to have strong Community Based Management Approach and water cost and pricing chain to manage the scarce water resources efficiently and effectively.’
· ‘I understood the importance of division of responsibilities specifically on the policy, implementation and regulation mandates. Also the importance to segregate the mandate on implementation and regulation to avoid conflict of interest. The involvement of water users at various level of decision making process and implementation is also key.’
After attending the face to face workshop, participants became aware of the importance of a reliable data baseline for managing water and sanitation, and how the absence of such data has negatively impacted the capacity of MoWHS and its partners in planning and budgeting water services. They also gained knowledge in data collection and survey sampling methods. This was mentioned in the evaluation questionnaire of the face to face workshop and during the final closing online meeting of the TMT.

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value:
The participants in the two in depth online trainings became aware of the importance of gender inclusive governance when it comes to all the phases of the public policy making cycle. According to the representative of the requesting organisation, as a result of the training, there is now a commitment in MoWHS to improve the mainstreaming of gender in all its water programmes.
Special attention will be paid to gender equality in the problem identification phase and during public decision making processes. The MoWHS stated that they gained a better understanding of how water problems faced by men and women are different, and that they should be dealt with accordingly.
